The most important factors that shape the distribution and demography of populations are natural increases in population size (the number of births minus the number of deaths), net migration, and environmental factors, such as water supply and climate conditions
32– 34 . T. austromongolica and T. chinensis are perennial species with strong tolerance and adaptability; these species blossom and bear fruit 2–3 years after germination. Therefore, both species produce numerous seeds in spring, summer, and autumn. Population growth rates are also influenced by the rates of migration; the small seeds of Tamarix species have white hairs on one end that enable long-distance wind or water dispersal
35 , resulting in rapid increases in populations and dispersal along the entire river if environmental conditions are suitable.
